Authors:
Sara Niae, Chompoonek Yurayart, Naris Thengchaisri,
Panpicha Sattasathuchana
Title:
Prevalence and in vitro antifungal susceptibility of
commensal yeasts in the external ear canal of cats
Keywords:
cat external ear canal, commensal yeasts, in-vitro
antifungal susceptibility
Abstract:
Background: Lifestyle factors such as hair length,
frequency of ear cleaning and bathing, age, cat rearing, and sex may
contribute to opportunistic yeast infections in the external ear canal
of cats. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of commensal yeast
organisms in cats external ear canal, evaluate predisposing lifestyle
factors, and test the susceptibility of Malassezia pachydermatis to
antifungal agents. Results: A total of 53 cats (33 male and 20 female)
seronegative for feline leukemia virus and feline immunodeficiency virus
were enrolled in the study. Mean age (± standard deviation [SD]) was
6.04 (± 3.49) years. Fungal cultures and polymerase chain reaction tests
were performed to identify yeast species from the external ear canal.
The association between lifestyle factors and the presence of M.
pachydermatis was evaluated using Fishers exact test. Susceptibility of
M. pachydermatis to antifungal agents was also analyzed. M.
pachydermatis was the most recovered yeast species, with a prevalence of
50.94% (95% confidence interval [CI]: 36.8464.94%). There was an
association between hair length and a positive culture for M.
pachydermatis (p=0.0001). The odds of a negative culture for M.
pachydermatis among short-haired cats was 11.67 (95% CI, 3.2242.24)
times higher than among long-haired cats (p=0.0002). There was also an
association between frequency of ear cleaning and presence of M.
pachydermatis (p=0.007). The odds of a negative culture for M.
pachydermatis in cats that were receiving ear cleaning at intervals of
≤2 weeks was 5.78 (95% CI, 1.6719.94) times more than those cats
receiving ear cleaning at intervals greater than 2 weeks or never
(p=0.0055). Ranges of minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) and
minimum fungicidal concentrations for itraconazole, ketoconazole,
miconazole, and terbinafine against M. pachydermatis were ≤0.0634 and
≤0.063≥32, ≤0.0638 and 0.125≥32, ≤0.063≥32 and 0.5≥32, and ≤0.0161 and
0.1258 µg/ml, respectively. Conclusions: M. pachydermatis was the most
commonly found yeast organism in the external ear canal of healthy cats.
Hair length and frequency of ear cleaning played a role in the
colonization of M. pachydermatis. All M. pachydermatis isolates were
susceptible to all antifungal agents tested with various MIC
levels.
